text: hey y'all  , maybe my question sounds silly or dumb but can't help it am totally confused and need some directions , so the thing is that in my app there's a feature where user can download the files which is someone sent to him assume it as a chat app , so am able to download the file using the url but the problem is that how am going to deal with the files that user have already downloaded  ? because right now what am doing is not so efficient ,  how whatsapp  deal with their feature they do the same thing too  ? any idea what should i do ???

:sweat_smile: i told ya it may sound dumb , see i'm downloading files from url but once i downloaded a file i don't want to download the same file again instead the button which invokes the action of downloading should open the downloaded file
can you check first if file with that name already exists?
okay but how am gonna do that ? i know how to check if file exists but i don't know the name of file which is linked with url
is it what i need right ?
oh i think i got it i mean you got it , i should also retrieve the name of file with url and check firstly if there's a file with that name or not
if it’s a resource, commonly you’d get it like <http://yourdomain.com/files/fileName.ext>
in this case you can just check fileName.ext
:yay: that was easy hahaha then i expected
Hey guys, I have a question performance wise.
I feel that it’s better to hold a couple of variables in memory. Then calculate / get them everytime in a touch event.
I need to do quite a few checks while drag n dropping something. (There is a lot of custom features, like auto scrolling while drag n dropping etc etc)
It’s better to hold the constant values in memory instead of calculating them right. For example, getting the screen height
Which gets the variables via the context in the resources
thought it was a constant somewhere
memory impact for a few vars should be neglible
of course you can always measure it
No, screen height is not calculated. It’s indeed a variable.
Only weird thing. I start a auto scroll handler that repeats itself when it auto scroll should continue
When I use my stylus (Note 4) it works perfect, when I do it by normal touch. It seems sluggish / laggy
I do a check in ACTION_MOVE:
if the touch position is still in the “auto scroll area”, auto scroll handler should stay repeating itself.
If no move, it stay repeating itself
Any idea why it feels sluggish by normal touch but works perfect with the stylus?

Hey anyone can tell me how to reduce skipped frame warning.
I have tried object intialization on different thread plus dB call in async task but still getting 200 framed skipped.

when you have performance issues please do not guess at what they are. Instead use the tools to figure out the root problems. Aka profile your code from the CPU tab (click profile, run the problem spot, then click profile again to stop)
figure out which method or methods (typically) has a low number of calls but a high number of relative inclusive time or exclusive time
It will sound stupid :grinning: but can you provide any link where I can find how to do all this stuff. B'z I have never used it. :sweat:

​

text: what are you looking for us to tell you? :stuck_out_tongue:
<@U0F5VSCNA>: please do not use the Hungarian notation
Probably should tell us more about what we’re reviewing
Also, +1 to not using Hungarian notation

attachments.title: Post: Just Say mNo to Hungarian Notation
attachments.text: Hungarian notation is a plague on Android development. Its proliferation is nothing more than a misinterpretation and justification an erroneous copy/paste.
attachments.fallback: Jake Wharton: Post: Just Say mNo to Hungarian Notation

text: Been really infected with `Optionals` in Swift as of late. And stumbled across Guava Optionals which seem to fit the same thing.
I won’t put Guava in my app
but Kotlin would do what you want
I join the kotlin channel - most recent discussion is about styles and themes. awesome :stuck_out_tongue:
<@U061HDV96>: The snippet looks like it’s from Jake Wharton … must be good
oh goodness you’ve asked that optionals question in so many places
Hungarian notation is _everywhere_ in my team’s project.
So then there is the conflict of remaining consistent or not.
<@U060Q7J2Y>: What’s wrong with them being mutable?
<@U0C1FB3PF>: thanks for checking, would appreciate it
well I mean in this model, I want them to be able to change? i haven’t written a lot of multithreaded apps
<@U0F5VSCNA>: most people use immutable objects with the builder pattern
<@U053LEHJN>: builder pattern isnt necessarily for that.
Nope. All network calls on the main thread.
its more about avoiding telescoping constructors with optional params
but most have a copy constructor that lets you easily modify an object's field or fields
though I guess that's less Builder pattern and more "has copy constructor" and/or "supports named & optional parameters"
… as long as you aren’t passing the same model across threads then all should be fine?
how would you make the above model thread safe as you guys are talking about
so if I grabbed data from a db and created a java object, if I want to persist changes back into the db, I would have to create a new instance of the model instead of reusing the old one?
<@U0F5VSCNA>: yeah, just imagine you're working with bytes instead of references
also depends on how you are doing your DB setup
realm uses mutable objects IIRC (never used it)
but that was for a job, so I guess it doesn't really count
interesting, I would think creating `new` instances vs. using old ones would be mem inefficient
it is, but it doesn't matter for most applications
ART's GC is more than adequate these days

Cases were you want to worry about memory efficiency:
1. Game engines
2. Extremely large data sets (which you probably wouldn't be working with on a mobile device anyway)
have you used Guava Optionals before <@U053LEHJN> ?
and when I'm working in Java, I just use @Nullable and @NonNull
that last bit answers my next question if Kotlin wasn’t an option – though looks like I got more learning to do bout Kotlin
